text: <@U08GFT5V5> IIRC, _Byte wise_ operations are planned for 1.1

Those operations aren't supported natively on the JVM. Java makes it possible by auto-promoting to int.
Kotlin was trying to explicit, hence no direct support, but I think they'd also be taking a slightly similar approach in the planned implementation

<@U1HM4MPLJ|kingsley> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/kingsley/F3GEQLRDW/Untitled.kt|Untitled> and commented: Since `wait` doesn't have a backing field, you can safely ignore the annotations

file.name: Untitled.kt
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
@JsonField(name = arrayOf("wait"))
var _wait: String? = null
​
@Ignore
var wait: Duration? = null

initial_comment.comment: Since `wait` doesn't have a backing field, you can safely ignore the annotations

text: <@U1HM4MPLJ> I still want to have a backing field so it doesn't have to parse it every time
Hmmm. Okay. Make sense
Kotlin doesn't have something like C#'s `out`, right?
`out` in Kotlin is related to generic typing. I do no suppose that is what you were referring to. Is it?
Modified the code snippet above ^
No :confused:
Does `field ?: _wait?.parseDuration()` still set `field`?
It is possible for `_wait` to be set but not `wait`
`_wait` is exposed to Realm, but `wait` is not
So when it comes from Realm, you can still get `wait`
Oh. Shit. field should be set lazily in the `get()`
Modified again ^
Ya, but is that more readable? :confused:
Well. I suppose it might just be easier to go with your original snippet :thinking_face:

What do I need lateinit for when I have defaults?

Wut?
The error is basically useless to me
You know, The codegen is trying to inject the field directly, but as Kotlin has the backing fields as private
lateinit changes the field visibility to that of the getter
Either that, or `@JvmField` annotation to strip off getter/setters
lateinit is not allowed on nullable properties :confused:
<@U1HM4MPLJ> the docs of Realm don't mention anything about using `@JvmField`

I don't know about Realm. But I'd guess it's trying to inject the field directly. Since Kotlin makes the backing field private, that will be impossible. So, you need a way to make it accessible by Realm's codegen. Either lateinit (doesn't work with nullable properties) or @JvmField (strips getters/setters, and leaves field with expected visibility modifier) should help here
<https://github.com/realm/realm-java/blob/master/examples/kotlinExample/src/main/kotlin/io/realm/examples/kotlin/model/Person.kt>

Anytime I open a Java class in a mixed project, it just feels overwhelming, and I find myself converting it to Kotlin
Did that on a project until I had 100% Kotlin
Was quite fun :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U1HM4MPLJ> do you use lateinit in your POJOs? (POKOs?)
It seems reasonable
Depends
I'm currently making everything I get from my API lateinit
Except for Strings that I set to empty just in case
And that Realm workaround
And primitive types...
most times, I make them constructor parameters, so no lateinit
I can't add any getters in the constructor
So I prefer to keep them all in the body
I still use GSON, so it injects them via reflection anyway
Properties with custom getters I put in the body. Mostly those without backing fields
Is this that big of a problem for my case btw? I don't think it is, but I just want to double check: <https://i.imgur.com/R83lgAm.png>
I also put everything in the body, if I have a constructor that takes a parcel as source, so I just initialize all the properties from there
Realm forces me to use open everywhere
open is just ugly
I was looking into a colleagues code, he does Java EE. I just had to give up

He had something like:
`@Config("retries.max") protected open var maxRetries: Int? = null`

protected because it can't be public (per spec)
open because some proxy will be injecting it later

All just feels very unnatural
Yaaaa
That's a bit like using Realm now
I think it might be a good idea if Kotlin exposes a way to disable the final by default (maybe a prefix keyword before `class`?)
Sometimes, non-final just the logical way to go, and `open` everywhere isn't exactly fascinating

The `protected` I mentioned above would have been unnecessary in Java, since omitting the modifier simply implies `package private` (meets spec). Fortunately/unfortunately, Kotlin doesn't understand that concept
<@U1HM4MPLJ> that's what `internal` is for
much more useful IMO
<@U053LEHJN> yea, I understand the idea behind `internal`. But in the Java world, is really a mangled public visibility. For the particular case, public visibility isn't supported. Hence `protected`

The spring community wants that final disabler flag for a while now :D Always annoying to mark everything as open manually. But iirc you can lateinit config properties like the one above too to get rid of the nullable type.
